_S9iwfKA2Q9uCpNGDJkcng.text: Great option for an indoor and aircooled food court. The range of options for dishes are extensive and cover a lot of the classics for Singapore such as hainan chicken rice, char kway teow, nasi goreng, etc. What puts this indoor food court above the other indoor options is the price and the quality. The prices are a few dollars higher than the outdoor food courts but are also a few dollars cheaper than comparable indoor food courts (ion mall, rasapura masters, etc.)I tried several dishes and really enjoyed the prawn noodles and grilled mackeral. The taiwanese fried salmon and vegetable soup was also pretty good.If your looking to escape the heat or introduce some friends to dishes in Singapore then Food Republic is a great option!

6NiKMWKrVhn9cOeORZSNpA.text: Food quality is very good, but not much better than the Kopitiam foodcourt downstairs. Food can be quite expensive here, especially the cai png stall. I ordered 2 Meat 2 Veg, and it was ~$11.50. However, this cai png is around "zi char" quality, and they have a few dishes that you wouldn't find in a normal cai png stall, such as pork ribs. Much each to buy drinks here, compared to the Kopitiam foodcourt downstairs, since they have moving cars around that offer drinks. During peak hours, it can also be very hard to find seats here, so come during non-peak hours. I recommend the chicken rice and the prawn noodle stall. Most of these stalls are very authentic and almost worth the price.

KBD-KtRQo51DjrQR0x9MdQ.text: After shopping in VivoCity, we were hungry and needed something to eat. We had passed by FoodRepublic, which is on the top floor, when we had taken the Sentosa Express earlier, so we decided to just stop by to eat here.I had also seen a Food Republic when I was in Hong Kong as well, but from what I know, it's simply just a food court, with not much in common (although they both had a Toast Box...). This one is designed like an old street.There are a lot of different food options, but from what I saw, they were all different types of Asian foods (e.g.: Taiwanese, Vietnamese, Thai, etc). There are also some drink stations available as well, although there are vendors pushing drink carts around as well.Since it was our last day in Singapore, I decided I just wanted some Chicken Rice, so I went to Sergeant Hainanese Chicken Rice, which is on the right side once you walk in.I ordered the Duo Set ($10.80), which comes with two kinds of chicken, veggies, egg/tofu, and a soup. They even gave us 2 soups since they knew we were sharing. The food was okay and plentiful, but around double the price of a similar set meal elsewhere (at least where I went). Also, for supposedly being 2 kinds of chicken, I couldn't tell the difference either by appearance or taste.Overall I wasn't too impressed. I didn't mind eating here since I was convenient since we were shopping, but you can definitely get better food at a cheaper price elsewhere.

photos.caption: Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore. Duo Set ($10.80) from Sergeant Hainanese Chicken Rice - okay food, but overpriced!
Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore. Designed to look like an old street area

n0oXrErSUQsEKAIOQxrtxA.text: at the end of our visit to santos's island. we had lunch here. so many selection to choose from. we had hong kong noodles soup with lots of veggies, indonesian chicken and rice with the best samba tumis i ever taste, indonesia's chicken bbq, red bean peanut kachang, tu tu kueh, mango mango kachang and different varieties of fresh cut fruits.

photos.caption: Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore. glass noodle with many noodles
Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore. tu tu kuih

Y3VU0aA9mNQKHEli3VOeNA.text: Run of the mill food court. Basic versions of dishes. Lots of people because it's affordable and quick. Used plates and cups were not cleared in time. Patrons standing everywhere waiting for an available seat.

w0OuXV1zcbUgcMVWEhJn4Q.text: One word for the whole place: overpriced. Does that mean you should not eat here? Not necessarily. Options in Vivocity are generally not cheap. More affordable options are either non-air conditioned or super crowded. At least the food here is good. I tried the prawn noodles with soup. The amount of ingredients was decent and the soup was delicious. My friend had roasted duck rice and added roasted pork. The duck was tender but the pork was full of fat so avoid if it's not your kind of thing. There are also rave reviews about the mixed vegetables and Chinese handmade noodle stalls. Just don't get a shock when you find yourself paying $7 and upwards for a dish.

photos.caption: Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore. Prawn mee and laksa stall

DWC8CvOuZv6Ts16lBzPd3A.text: Mmm I like this place. This was my first experience dining on Singaporean cuisine. My friend and I spent the morning at Senotsa, which has a shuttle that connects to this place. We chose Food Republic since there are a million different options so you get a lot of variety depending on what you feel like eating. Lots of traditional local dishes for very cheap prices! We had the wanton noodles and hokkien prawn mee for lunch. Everyone is sold in small-large sizes which is cool. Ahh so yummy! I loved the wanton noodles and the hokkien prawn was quite good as well. They sell desserts on carts that are pushed around (reminded me of dim sum style) though you can also go to one of the stalls. For dessert, we had soursop ice and ice kacang, yum yum. Loved the soursop--it was the first time I've ever tried it.Basically, my Singaporean friend described this place as a hawker with AC. It has a bunch of different stalls selling different types of food, and then you just grab a seat. It was pretty crowded when we went around 1pm, but as we walked toward the back, there was a lot of empty seating. So if you go, be sure to walk around to the back if the front area is too filled. So much yummy food for a decent price (Though still higher than hawker of course) but then again you're paying a little bit more for the AC and comfort, so I think it's worth it. From the tourist perspective, it's a great opportunity to try a lot of Singaporean foods.tldr; great place great food, def worth going to if you happen to be in Vivocity.

photos.caption: Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore

rUtJv1QUbgzepTf8n0slpg.text: This food court has a bit of old feel to it. Making you feel like your outside but it has air con! I had a Mini Seafood Hotpot (steamboat) (under $ 6.00SD) - this is a really nice and filling meal to share if you want a light lunch or if your hungry to eat all of it on your own. Not spicy at all the soup is very creamy  full of flavour of the sea. You get quite alot of prawn meatballs and fish that has been deep fried and into the broth. Also lots of chinese cabbage too. Add another ($2sd) you can have a choice of variety of noodles to compliment the dish from wheat noodles to flat rice noodles. The sauce on the right is fish sauce with hint of chilli and sauce on the left is chilli but with a hint of sour lime.

photos.caption: Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore

yKm41xZ49eR2SMUJuQHElw.text: i love how they make cheap eats not look and feel cheap. The dark wood interiors with the chinese red lantern is a nice touch.All you want to taste, eat and feel are housed here.Very busy but you can always grab a seat.Great for families or  big parties.

photos.caption: Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore

49HMir7TsmRLn8WUvupR2Q.text: One of those upclass-tity food courts.Every dish is probably $2 to $4 more pricey. Quality depends on luck, unless you have had previous experiences with specific stalls.I prefer the Indonesian stall, and grilled chicken is my repeat order. Unpretentious, and it taste like grilled chicken with a sweet shallot oinion-y fragrance. It meat is moist, the rice is fluffy, but the sides are average. The soup, hmmm.... probably to rinse your utensils.

yOAmxMZotETzM5gymfFaGg.text: Prawn kuay tiao with Pork Ribs is nice. The pork ribs is not really tender but flavourful. Soup is thick and tasty!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore. Prawn kuay tiao with Pork Ribs

Aa2Wacv5AEd8gIjVrlOOjQ.text: Ok Food Court with a touch of local greediness. From Udon Beef, Hokkien Mee to Fried Carrot Cake, Hot Padang Dishes to Nasi Lemak, but no Singaporean Chicken Rice?!We tried the Hokkien Mee, it was good portion with good sauce. The funny part is when we purchased avocado juice from the juice stall. The cashier lady skimmed a couple dimes over the cash machine price. We just laughed it off. Overall an Ok experience while we were in Singapore.

DM5acAHBeVDu6Cwc-6F7Gg.text: Food Republic at Vivocity is one of the few places I will be willing to go to at a drop of a hat because of the awesome variety of food it has to offer here. I personally find this place better than the Wisma one. I find it ironic that hawker style food were demolished over the years and now we are desperately trying to recreate the same ambiance our grandparents and parents had in the 40s/50s/60s... with bright lights, less stuffiness and air con. But oh well, Gen X and Y kids like me were sold by the ambiance because when we were born here, these places seems to cease to exit already (Perhaps the only 'authentic' one left is the one along China Town road). I love Jessie's Rojak here. She has a black and white version of rojak with vegan options. The ba chor mee here is also nice. Frankly, I come here more for the rojak because she serves adequate rojak sauce to go with it. If you ask me to compare, I'll say her rojak is on par with the Hoover Road Rojak store at Whampoa food center sans the long queue at her store. But that is in my opinion lah. So do give her rojak a try when you are there, it's situated next to the BBQ chicken wing store.. she should be there reading a newspaper or a magazine when you walked by her store.

photos.caption: Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore. Rojak

o24z7WWhNpXn07b4uRtpDA.text: Good food court with tons of local eats. Love the Hokkien Mee, Pie Ti, Rojak etc. It's always crowded but there're seats deep in the food court. Reasonable prices too

tfwRU4TCpVCQw1SVqhHlaw.text: Food was ok here.  Yes, it might appear more easy to order and find food there, because it all is more organized than other hawker centers, but on the other hand does feel less authentic plus the food reply was below the average I was used for other places. Now with these places being even more expensive, I don't see a particular reason to go there once agai

7hNmmq1R7kyjxU7mJVLxaw.text: Food Republic is one of my favorite food courts because they often have a good selection of tasty local food. It is quite appropriate to introduce your foreign friends to some of the local selection of food at a relatively inexpensive and air conditioned environment. But one thing that I dislike about this specific Food Republic outlet is the layout. Sure, it is spacious and has ample seats to deal with large crowds at VivoCity on weekends, but the layout of the stalls is pretty far apart and confusing. You may find yourself walking in rounds if you are not familiar with the place or is going there for the first time. Overall, it is still a clean and comfortable environment to have a quick meal at.

photos.caption: Photo of Food Republic - Singapore, Singapore

gy2zjgae73ibl9-W7qHDxg.text: An interesting takes on a food court, recreating the old world charm of Singapore in the 40s/50s/60s with aged wooden beams and benches. old-school looking pushcarts and decoration. I like this particular Food republic for its good collection of quality stalls. Xin Sheng Ngoh Hiong is one of them, and a branch of Sergeant chicken rice, as well as the popular Heng Hwa restaurant, Putien.  Food starts from $4 at most stalls. Soy bean drink and you tiao, the Korean food stall, and sotong mee stall are also very decent.

z6zcu9yC2S9RNYFD3PASzA.text: So this food courts has everything you can ask for in Asian food and the braised short rib bun is the first thing you see as soon as you walk toward the flowery sign and a must have. you get 3 for 5 and this super tend, juicy pork rib is served is a bun just like peking duck and it a great start to your meal. I tried the hainanese roasted chicken with rice. Yummy, totally simple dish that just celebrates the tenderness and sweetness of chicken with a dash of fresh ginger sauce. my Hubby and his brother was sold on a special at the next door stall which was 6.50 for 2 meats and their Indo chicken and Fish was so tasty. I was surprise how much I like the Fish as it has a little crisp skin and tender inside, not to sweet or salty. The end my wonderful lunch I had to get a fried dough or you tao with soy milk. That was so good that I had to get another order to go.

Eu20JzgXXr3UOasngIIcIg.text: I can confidently say Food Republic is one of the better food courts in Singapore. Despite higher prices, the food selection is generous and flavorful. My favorite picks would be the Nasi Lemak/Padang store at the entrance and the Dim Sum restaurant within the food court. The great thing about the Nasi Padang stall here is the good sized chicken drumsticks, be it the deep fried or curry version! If you're game for dessert, give the tu tu kueh a try! The sweetness of the coconut shavings and the texture of the velvety flour is an absolute winner!
